text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So, what, what other questions do you have? Patient: I read the, the, the information which you gave me. I - trepeditation about the, my actual response to all of this. And, I won’t know that until we start. So. I really don’t have anything other than - I wanna get it started. It’s my fourth visit, and you’re a great guy. But, next time, I want you to stick a needle in my arm or something. Doctor: Yeah. So, yeah we, you know, my problem with this stuff is, you know, the hormone therapy does good on it’s own. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, we are adding more into it, so we can’t always tell you what the, um, adding in the chemo is gonna do. We can’t tell you what the surgery is gonna do. But, the outcome really is a number of men that don’t need therapy once we stop everything. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, that would be great! If, you know, uh, we don’t see it - more, it is a zero. The testosterone has recovered. That would be ideal. Um. The next step is, you know, that we don’t get rid of your cancer with all of this and that your PSA goes up in the future. And, is that a longer time to get to that point or is it sort of like, even if we just did one thing, it’s all on-time? Patient: I do have one question. The, the rib. (pause) Doctor: Uh, because, we, we don’t normally cut out the ribs. I mean, that’s where we’re gonna offer radiation to that spot. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: So, that’s gonna treat that spot. Patient: And that would be later after the chemo cycles.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I think it’s going to come pretty quickly. So the company that our group because our group invented it. It’s a company in France, that is a very experienced company developing new uh radioactive things. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That company just got bought by N___ Patient: Oh. Doctor: for five billion dollars. So there’s now a kind of uh a big shift. So I think it’s going to happen. Patient: So it’s going to be? Doctor: But up until now, it’s been this kind of almost called hit or miss, and just because of the way we did things in the U.S., it hasn’t. It’s been very frustrating. And I told you I went to Turkey to some little hospital taking care of this guy. We can give him We invented it. I can’t give it at my hospital. Patient: Oh. Oh. Doctor: So it’s been used in that way around the world but not, I’m not allowed to. Patient: That’s so tough. I see. Family Member: So it has pretty good results in Germany?

text: Family Member: Spine, ribs, and shoulder? (pause11sec) Doctor: Yeah. The one, the one thing we see also with, we’ve seen with the testosterone, is something called a flair. Meaning spots are there- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - but we don’t see them very well, and then we give a drug like that, they can get more intense so they show up. And I think these are spots that are, you know, been there for probably a year or two just below the radar. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It’s just a matter of, you know, we’re seeing them now. Uh, and whether the testosterone helped to see them better, that’s what we see with some other guys. So, uh, but I think certainly there’s enough there that we’ve got to keep- Family Member: Do something else? Yeah. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Alright. Doctor: So I will call you probably Friday- Patient: Okay. Doctor: With some information. Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member: I’m sorry; say that one more time. You say it’s two? What are the two again? Doctor: The -the two general like avenues that we could go; one is radiotherapy to target that lymph node. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And we have a trial to do that through H__. And the other one is to skip the radiotherapy and go directly to hormone therapy. And then we have a trial looking to see whether combining something with hormone therapy is better than hormone therapy alone. Patient: Uh hum. Family Member: Well what is the something? Doctor: Something is an oral medication. It’s a new oral hormonal therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s a second hormone therapy that given in connection with the injection of hormone therapy we believe may produce better outcomes than just injecting the hormone by itself. Patient: But even with that, that’s still just to slow it down; it’s not to cure anything. It’s kind of take it to add a little bit more Doctor: That’s correct. Everything that we have discussed today frankly is not really curative in terms of its potential. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: So we know still it’s invisible somewhere, so we can target what we can see. And we can still deal with you know what we can’t see. If that’s the combination of your thinking in terms of correct or that is a possibility? Doctor: I’m thinking that in terms of the sequence if you get the radiotherapy first. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That does not close the door to getting hormone therapy down the line. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: You start with the hormone therapy, the other option is going to disappear very quickly. And a radiation oncologist is not going to know what to target. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It would be very different if the spot was in the bone. Bone metastasis takes a very long time to disappear. Sometimes you know a small one can take up to a year to disappear. So oftentimes when a cancer is involved, when they start the hormone therapy about three months later, a week later, two weeks later you talk to the radiation oncologist and by the time he starts the radiation planning which might be six to eight weeks later, the spot is still where he can see it, he can zap it and target that. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And with a lymph node, uh if we start the hormone therapy even like a couple of weeks before that thing’s going to disappear; he won’t know what he’s targeting. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So all I’m saying is in theory that-

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
